framework.framework_title: Writing a Dissertation, Research Report or Long Essay

framework_intro.para: Here is a framework to help you write a long assignment. There are spaces for you to add the content of your assignment.

commentary.para: You may have to write a long assignment as part of your course assessment. This may be a dissertation, long essay, project, research report, etc.
The purpose of these assignments is to show the examiner that you:
- have gained research skills, knowledge and understanding from your course;
- can apply the methods of your field to a topic of your own choice;
- can complete an extended, in-depth piece of work.
Dissertations can range from about 10 000 words at undergraduate level to about 30 000 words for some Master's degrees.
Long essays may be slightly shorter, ranging from 2 000 to 10 000 words.
References, appendices, the abstract, and front matter (title page, table of contents, etc.) are not usually included in the word count.
A dissertation may have all or only some of the following parts, usually presented in this order.
Note: requirements and conventions vary in different fields, departments and institutions. Always consult your tutor/supervisor and departmental guidelines for specific details.

step.label: How is the main part structured?

commentary.para: Requirements and conventions vary in different fields, departments and institutions. Always consult your tutor/supervisor and departmental guidelines for specific details.
You can see two typical structures at Preparing to Write, by clicking the Writing tab (above).
For more details on individual sections, look at the relevant templates in the iWriter.

checklist.point:
Carrying out a research study.
</br>TIP
Back up your files as you collect data and write up your work.

Decide on a structure for your writing.
</br> Check requirements with your tutor/supervisor.
</br>Long texts consist of several shorter sections which you may also have to write as separate assignments, e.g. Introduction, Literature Review.
</br>Look at the individual templates in the iWriter for more detailed information on each section.
</br>TIP
Choose titles and headings that are short but informative. The examiner needs to know the content of each chapter and section clearly.

Planning the sections.
</br>TIP
</br>1. Chapters do not have to be the same length. Each chapter should be as long as necessary to cover the material.
</br>2. Do not be worried by the total number of words. Individual sections are often the same length as assignments you have written already.
</br>3. Divide the assignment into manageable sections and build up your writing section by section.

Revising
</br>TIP
Get someone else to proofread your text. They often notice problems more easily.
Look at the Language Banks, Grammar Focus notes and more in the iWriter template for the section you wish to write.
Have I checked the accuracy of my material?
Have I checked that there is no repetition?
Have I used appropriate academic language?
Have I checked vocabulary, grammar, spelling and punctuation?
Have I formatted references consistently, using a suitable convention?
Have I followed all the requirements for submission?

paragraph.name: Writing a Dissertation, Research Report or Long Essay
paragraph.desc: An overview of the parts and structure of a long assignment, such as a dissertation, long essay, project, research report, etc.
paragraph.tip:
TIP Long texts consist of several shorter sections which you may also have to write as separate assignments, e.g. Introduction, Literature Review.
</br>TIP Refer to the other sections of the iWriter for templates giving detailed information, tips and language suggestions for each part of a typical dissertation.

paragraph.name: Title page
paragraph.desc:
Contains the dissertation title, your name, department, degree and date of submission.
There may be a specific form of words required, e.g. ‘A dissertation submitted for the degree of …’.

paragraph.name: Abstract
paragraph.desc: A short summary of the whole text, usually 100–200 words
paragraph.tip: TIP Look at the templates: Writing an Abstract 1: Physical and Life Sciences OR Writing an Abstract 2: Social Sciences OR Writing an Abstract 3: Medicine.

paragraph.name: Acknowledgements
paragraph.desc: Thanks are often given in the following order: </br>1. your tutor/supervisor </br>2. other academic help </br>3. technical and financial support; participants in your study </br>4. friends and relations
paragraph.tip: TIP This is an optional section.

paragraph.name: Table of Contents
paragraph.desc: A list of all the parts of your dissertation with page numbers
paragraph.tip: TIP Include chapter titles, headings and sub-headings, if used.

para.prompt: Draft your Table of Contents here.

paragraph.name: List of figures, tables or other graphic matter
paragraph.tip: TIP Each graphic element should have a title and a number, e.g. Table 2.4 is the fourth table in Chapter 2.

content.prompt: Type your list of figures and tables here.

para.prompt: Type your list of figures and tables here.

paragraph.name: Chapters 1, 2, etc.
paragraph.tip:
TIP See 'Preparing to Write' for the typical structure for your own field.
</br>TIP Refer to individual templates in the iWriter for detailed information, tips and language suggestions for each section that you are using.

content.prompt: Draft or outline the body of your dissertation here.

para.prompt: Draft or outline the body of your dissertation here.

paragraph.name: References/bibliography
paragraph.desc: A list of all the works mentioned in your dissertation
paragraph.tip:
TIP Do not include references to works that you do not mention.
</br>TIP Check the accepted format for a bibliography with your supervisor. Also look at the template: Writing from Sources.

paragraph.name: Appendix 1, 2, etc.
paragraph.desc: Appendices are extra matter which supports your dissertation, but is not part of it, e.g. a survey questionnaire in social science.
